title: Serval and Colorful Array (Hard Version)
statementHtml:
This is the hard version of the problem. The difference between the versions is that in this version, n≤4⋅105. You can hack only if you solved all versions of this problem.

Serval has a magic number k (k≥2). We call an array r colorful if and only if:

You are given an array a consisting of n integers between 1 and k. It is guaranteed that each integer between 1 and k appears in a at least once. You can perform the following operation on a:

Find the minimum number of operations needed to make at least one subarray∗ of a colorful. It can be shown that this is always possible under the constraints of the problem.

∗An array b is a subarray of an array a if b can be obtained from a by the deletion of several (possibly, zero or all) elements from the beginning and several (possibly, zero or all) elements from the end.
inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases t (1≤t≤1000). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers n and k (2≤k≤n≤4⋅105) — the length of the array a and Serval's magic number.

The second line contains n integers a1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤k) — the elements of the array a. It is guaranteed that each integer between 1 and k appears in a at least once.

It is guaranteed that the sum of n over all test cases does not exceed 4⋅105.
outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output a single integer — the minimum number of operations needed to make at least one subarray of a colorful.
noteHtml:
In the first test case, since the subarrays [a1,a2]=[1,2] and [a2,a3]=[2,1] are already colorful, we do not need to perform any operations. Thus, the answer is 0.

In the second test case, we can swap a1 and a2 to obtain [1,2,1,3––––––,1,1,2], which has a colorful subarray [a2,a3,a4]=[2,1,3]. And the given array initially does not have any colorful subarrays, so the answer is 1.
